around batches we had this hypothesis that if a batch had a similar run through the
entire production process as another batch then those batches probably had similar yields so kind of intuitively makes

yield and patterns that were associated with high yield and get an understanding of what's driving this product variation
so the result was we were able to build a model that accounted for over 50 percent of product variation

so that's a big deal and industry recognized that in fact this particular analytics project data

now back to the story so we can get a little geeky here so
we had this assumption this hypothesis that similar production runs through the the process would result in
similar yield characteristics so we needed to do is compare a bunch of
time series together and so we implemented something called dynamic time warping
and dynamic time warping is really nice because it can give us a measure of similarity between two time series
and those time series don't necessarily need to be on the same time scale since we're dealing with a biological
manufacturing process one piece of the process could finish in five hours and then
a different batch could run through that process and it may take seven hours so dynamic time warping could account
for this different the different time scales so we ended up doing is
implementing this through a mapreduce paradigm which is actually really important because even if a single
machine were able to do all these computations the computational run time would have been well over a year between
a year and a half to two years and because of the scale up skill down nature of hadoop and amazon web services
we're able to spin up the cluster compute capacity and finish the computations in about a day and then
when we're done we scaled it back down so it saves a year off compute compute time saves a bunch of money for for merc
so we end up with all these similarity measures and what do we do we sort the batches according to yield from
the lowest in the top left to the highest yield in the bottom right and we do a batch to batch similarity
comparisons and so if uh if time series look very similar for high yield batches we'll see
a bunch of red in the bottom right corner for that particular metric whether that's ph or auger speed or drip
rates of certain nutrients and if we see a big red dot in the top left corner that means that there were
similar patterns associated with low yield so what we're able to do then is go back
and look at the individual time series that are showing these clustering patterns
we can see that there are certain properties with the time series such as maybe the area under the curve and
certain parts of the time series or the slopes of the time series and use those as inputs into regression
models which then accounted for fifty percent of the product variation so when you think about the scope of
this problem this particular product they're selling billions of dollars of it per year
and to be able to understand the drivers of the yield that translates to millions of dollars of savings in savings
